node.title: Honouring the forgotten faces of the ANZAC legend
node.alt: A woman in a denim jacket stands in front of a wall of memorial to Australian soldiers
node.description: For the past ten years, Wiradjuri Elder Ruth Carney has gone to her community's ANZAC day service knowing the memory of her father and uncles are recognised.
node.content:
["For the past ten years, Wiradjuri Elder Ruth Carney has gone to her community's ANZAC day service in central west NSW knowing the memory of her father and uncles are recognised.", "Her family's service records are among more than 800 histories unearthed and digitised by semi-retired volunteer historian Sandra Smith, with support from the Australian War Memorial (AWM).", "Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised this story contains images of people who have died.", "For AWM Indigenous Liaison Officer Michael Bell, this work is a vital step in the journey towards reconciliation.", "\"Sandra does a marvellous job on her research, her genealogy, her trove searching to confirm Aboriginality, but also then to put the pieces together,\" he said.", "", "
Lance Corporal Richard Kirby was born in Dubbo, New South Wales and was working as a labourer when he enlisted in\u00a01915.\u00a0Kirby was fatally wounded in France\u00a0on 20 August 1918.(Supplied: Australian War Memorial)
", "With old records being digitised and the national archives finally cracked open, historians, biographers, researchers, and archivists across the country are beginning to shade in the gaps of Indigenous soldiers' contributions to Australia's war history.", "\"It wasn't until around 1917 that our Indigenous population was permitted to sign up, so I'll often find an Aboriginal person signing up saying they were Maori,\" said Ms Smith.", "\"Australia had a small population and I suspect it was running out of men when they were finally allowed to freely enlist.\"", "", "
Sandra Smith has unearthed the service histories of more than 800 Indigenous soldiers.(ABC Western Plains: Olivia Ralph)
", "For many families seeking answers, it is a story of hidden heritage and deathbed confessions.", "There are many famous servicemen and women from World War I\u00a0and World War II\u00a0whose descendants are only now identifying their First Nations heritage.\u00a0", "\"They made a choice to live the life the best they could under the freedoms that they were granted, or weren't granted, depending on which side of the coin you're on,\" said Mr Bell.", "", "
Ruth Carney's uncle, Ivan Robert Powell, served with the 62nd Transport Company\u00a0in New Guinea and Bougainville during World War Two(Supplied: Ruth Carney)
", "For many other families, it is a story of seeking credit long overdue.", "\"It will always be a question mark for me because they did their bit, but no one seemed to have done it until Sandra,\" Ms Carney said.", "\"It's just lovely to be recognised in the community, for his name to be on the wall with everybody else's.\"", "", "
Harold West and George Leonard were best mates and\u00a0enlisted together\u00a0at Goodooga in north-western New South Wales in August 1941.(Supplied: Australian War Memorial)
", "For historians like Ms\u00a0Smith, it is about setting work that will continue long after them.", "\"In the future, more records are going to come out, more people are going to come forward and I want it to be a resource for people to use and then add to,\" she said.", "\"I want it to be a work in progress.\""]
